title: Saquon Barkley likely to play vs. Cardinals; final decision to come from Giants soon
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Lorenzo's Locks are back on track after a winning week. Week 7 offers up juicy matchups and we are here to help you make money off of them. USA TODAY

The official proclamation that Saquon Barkley will play Sunday against Arizona may come as soon as Friday. For the time being, a coy Barkley is playing along with the team.

Asked several times Thursday about the possibility of returning from the high right ankle sprain that sidelined him for a month, the Giants’ star running back repeated time after time, “I’m just day-to-day.”

The smirk on Barkley’s face said it all.

After practicing Wednesday and Thursday, he may not be included on Friday’s injury report, which is the league-mandated vehicle for announcing that a player won’t play in a game. Giants coach Pat Shurmur prefers to extend the status of injuries until the league deadlines.

Still, expect Barkley and tight end Evan Engram, who missed the New England game with a sprained knee, to start against the Cardinals. Both have checked all the boxes on their rehab sheets.

Quarterback Daniel Jones can use the extra help in his matchup against Kyler Murray, the No. 1 overall pick, that has all the makings of an offensive shootout.

Engram is probably drooling after watching game tapes of the Cardinals’ pass defense. Arizona ranks last in the league in containing tight ends. Like Barkley, Engram has practiced two days in a row.

“It’s gonna be good getting back out there,” Engram said. “I’m going to be a kid in the candy shop again.”

Jones is likely eager to get Barkley back to the offense. The pair played only 23 snaps together in the Tampa Bay game before Barkley was injured. The Giants rallied to win without him and beat Washington the next week. Then came losses to Minnesota and New England that leaves the Giants at 2-4.

The time away from the game ate at Barkley. During his rehab, he was an early morning visitor to the weight room and the trainer’s room.

“When you get the game taken away from you, it makes you appreciate it even more,” Barkley said. “I know a lot of people call me a super-healer, but it’s a lot of hard work.”

Teammates talk about how the second-year star doesn’t assume anything. He’s among the hardest workers in a clubhouse that has been singled out by several assistant coaches for its professionalism.

“I always want to be out there,” Barkley said. “I get up every single morning and live my dream. I feel like a little kid again.”

The team thinks Barkley will bring out the best in Jones, their first-year investment at quarterback.

“If he’s ready to play, he’ll get a full complement (of the game plan),” offensive coordinator Mike Shula said. “If we have any hesitation at all…”

Barkley has no hesitations. He says he feels “pretty good” after making the necessary cuts in practice, something he couldn’t do when working out on the sidelines, away from his teammates.

Asked what he could do to help Jones, he answered: “Do what I do best. Be me.”

The Giants would appreciate that.
description: The smirk on Saquon Barkley’s face said it all. After practicing Wednesday and Thursday, the Giants RB may not be included on Friday’s injury report.
